questions.text: Which of the following is a congenital cause for the given finding?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The fundus image shows a "salt-and-pepper" pigmentary retinopathy, which is a classical ocular manifestation of congenital Rubella. Transplacental transmission from an infected mother can lead to congenital abnormalities affecting multiple organ systems. Among the ocular features, "salt-and-pepper" pigmentary retinopathy is reported along with cataract, anterior uveitis, glaucoma, and microphthalmos.

Other Option:

Mumps (Option B)

Mumps can occasionally lead to ocular complications such as iridocyclitis and interstitial keratitis.

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) (Option C):

Ocular features such as cataract, chorioretinitis, microphthalmos, keratitis, and optic atrophy are more common.

Varicella (VZV)(Option D):

Ocular features may include cataract, microphthalmos, chorioretinitis, optic disc hypoplasia, and optic atrophy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old PLHA presents for a routine ophthalmic evaluation. Fundus examination reveals multiple cotton-wool spots and a few retinal haemorrhages. The patient denies any visual symptoms. Which of the following statements about this condition is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Retinal microangiopathy is the most common form of retinopathy seen in individuals with AIDS, affecting as many as 70% of patients.
  • It presents with cotton-wool spots and/or retinal haemorrhages, often asymptomatic, and lesions disappear spontaneously within weeks. (Rules out option D)
  • It correlates with low CD4+ T cell count and higher plasma HIV-RNA levels and serves as a marker for increased CMV retinitis risk. (Rules out option A)
  • It is not caused by CMV infection directly (unlike CMV retinitis). (Rules out option C)

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS) is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS) is a general term used for eyes showing any level of dryness, irrespective of the underlying cause.
  • Xerophthalmia, in contrast, is specifically linked to vitamin A deficiency-related dry eye. (Rules out option A)
  • Xerosis indicates severe ocular dryness with keratinisation, often due to advanced conjunctival scarring. (Rules out option B)
  • Sjögren syndrome is an autoimmune condition where dry eye is one of the features, but KCS is not exclusive to it. (Rules out option D)

questions.text:
A 20-year-old patient with poorly controlled type 1 diabetes presents with sudden blurring of vision in both eyes. Fundus examination is normal, but slit-lamp evaluation shows the following lens finding:

Which of the following refractive changes is commonly observed prior to the development of this feature?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image shows snowflake cortical opacities
  • Snowflake cataracts are typically seen in poorly controlled type 1 diabetics, especially young patients.
  • Here, glucose is converted into sorbitol, which then builds up in the lens of the eye. This accumulation leads to excessive water absorption (osmotic overhydration) within the lens.
  • When this occurs to a mild extent, it can alter the refractive index of the lens, causing fluctuations in vision that correspond with blood sugar levels. Specifically, high blood sugar (hyperglycemia) can lead to nearsightedness (myopia), and the reverse is also true. (Rules out option B)
  • Over time, fluid-filled sacs (vacuoles) begin to form in the outer layer (cortex) of the lens. These can eventually develop into full-blown opacities, characteristic of cataracts. A distinct and rare form, known as classic diabetic cataract, presents as snowflake-like opacities in the cortex.
  • In diabetic patients, lens osmotic swelling doesn't improve accommodation; instead, it alters the refractive index passively, causing blurring. (Rules out option C)

Key Takeaways:

  • Hyperglycemia → Myopic shift due to osmotic swelling of the lens.
  • Fluctuations in blood glucose can cause temporary vision changes.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old male with type 2 diabetes mellitus presents for routine screening. Fundus examination shows:
A. Severe retinal haemorrhages in all 4 quadrants.
B. Venous beading in 2 quadrants.
C. Venous beading in 2 quadrants.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management step for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient meets the criteria for Severe NPDR (4-2-1 rule: severe haemorrhages in all 4 quadrants + venous beading in 2 quadrants).
  • Management: Review in 4 months, as progression to PDR can occur in up to 50%, and high-risk PDR in 15% within 1 year.

Explanation Of Other Options:

Review in 12 months (Option B): Patients without diabetic retinopathy are reviewed in 12 months.

Review in 2 months (Option C): Very Severe NPDR: Defined when 2 or more criteria for Severe NPDR are met. Management: Review in 2-3 months (high-risk PDR up to 45% in a year).

Urgent treatment should be initiated (Option D): High-risk PDR requires urgent treatment

Key Takeaways:

  • Severe NPDR: Review in 4 months (PDR risk up to 50%, high-risk PDR risk up to 15%).
  • Very Severe NPDR: Review in 2-3 months.
  • High-risk PDR: Requires urgent laser or surgical treatment.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy presents with decreased vision in both eyes. He has coarse blond hair, blue irises, malar flush, and a Marfanoid habitus. His parents report neurodevelopmental delay and a history of recurrent thrombotic episodes. Examination of the left eye reveals the following finding:

Which of the following statements about this condition is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient's Marfanoid habitus, neurodevelopmental delay, coarse blond hair, malar flush, and thrombotic predisposition, along with inferonasal lens dislocation, point towards homocystinuria.
  • Homocystinuria is an autosomal recessive disorder (Rules out option B) caused by defective metabolism of methionine, leading to accumulation of methionine and homocysteine.
  • The slit-lamp image shows a subluxated crystalline lens displaced inferonasally, characteristic of ectopia lentis seen in homocystinuria.

Explanation of Other Options:

The lens is typically dislocated superotemporally due to weak zonules rich in cysteine (Option A):

  • In homocystinuria, the lens typically dislocates inferonasally, not superotemporally.
  • Marfan syndrome is associated with superotemporal ectopia lentis due to a fibrillin-1 defect.

Ectopia lentis is rare in this condition and is more commonly associated with Marfan syndrome (Option D):

  • Ectopia lentis is almost universal in untreated homocystinuria by 25 years of age and is not rare.
  • While Marfan syndrome also causes ectopia lentis, the direction of dislocation differs.

questions.text:
A 10-day-old neonate presents with lethargy, poor feeding, and jaundice. The parents report that the infant's condition worsened after initiating milk feeds. Examination reveals the following lens finding:

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image demonstrates an "oil droplet" cataract - a distinctive lens opacity seen in galactosemia.
  • Galactosemia is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by the absence of the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GPUT).
  • These changes develop within the first few days or weeks of life in affected infants and may reverse if galactose (milk and milk products) is eliminated from the diet early.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • Mannosidosis presents with punctate lens opacities arranged in a spoke-like pattern in the posterior lens cortex, not oil droplet cataracts. (Rules out Option B)
  • Lowe syndrome causes universal cataract and sometimes microphakia, but it is an X-linked disorder with additional neuromuscular and renal involvement. (Rules out Option C)
  • Fabry disease presents with wedge- or spoke-shaped posterior cataracts (Fabry cataract) and vortex keratopathy, but not oil droplet opacities. (Rules out Option D)

Key Takeaways:

  • Galactosemia → Oil droplet cataract (reversible if treated early).
  • Mannosidosis → Spoke-like posterior lens opacities.
  • Fabry disease → Spoke-shaped posterior cataract + vortex keratopathy.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient with ceruloplasmin deficiency presents with the finding shown in the image (arrow). This patient is at risk of developing which of the following types of cataract?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In Wilson's disease (hepatolenticular degeneration), ceruloplasmin deficiency leads to abnormal copper deposition in tissues.

  • Kayser-Fleischer rings (as seen in the image) are due to fine copper deposits in Descemet's membrane of the cornea and are present in 95% of patients with neurological signs.
  • Another ocular manifestation is the anterior capsular "sunflower" cataract, characterised by copper deposition on the anterior lens capsule.
  • These changes may regress with penicillamine therapy, which chelates copper.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Christmas tree cataract (Option B):

  • Seen in myotonic dystrophy, not Wilson disease.
  • Appear as fine, iridescent cortical opacities that evolve into star-shaped or wedge-like opacities by the fifth decade.

Snowflake cataract (Option C):

  • Associated with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus, especially in young patients.
  • Characterised by cortical opacities resembling snowflakes, which can mature quickly or resolve spontaneously.

Shield-like cataract (Option D):

  • Occurs in atopic dermatitis.
  • Presents as a dense anterior subcapsular plaque that wrinkles the capsule, often bilateral and rapidly maturing.

questions.text:
A chronic hypertensive patient shows the following finding on retinoscopic examination (arrow):

What is the grade of hypertensive retinopathy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given fundus image shows hard exudates arranged in a macular star pattern

Grade 3 Hypertensive Retinopathy is characterised by:

  • All Grade 2 features (focal narrowing, AV nipping, copper wiring)
  • Retinal haemorrhages (dot, blot, flame-shaped).
  • Exudates: Chronic retinal oedema can lead to hard exudates arranged in a macular star pattern (as seen in the image).
  • Cotton-wool spots (soft exudates).

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Grade 1 (Option A):

  • Grade 1 only has mild generalised arteriolar narrowing without haemorrhages, exudates, or macular star.

Grade 2 (Option B):

  • Grade 2 includes focal narrowing, AV nipping, and copper wiring, but does not have haemorrhages or exudates.

D) Grade 4 (Option C):

  • Grade 4 is characterised by optic disc swelling (papilledema) in addition to Grade 3 changes, seen in malignant hypertension.

questions.text: Which of the following ocular findings is characteristically associated with Weill-Marchesani syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Weill-Marchesani syndrome is a systemic connective tissue disorder, often described as the converse of Marfan syndrome.

Ocular features:

  • Microspherophakia (small, spherical lens) → can cause pupillary block glaucoma and angle closure.
  • Ectopia lentis (50%) → Lens subluxation occurs inferiorly in late childhood or early adulthood. (Rules out Option B)

Inheritance: Autosomal recessive or dominant (AD caused by FBN1 gene mutations).

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Ectopia lentis in an upward direction (Option C): Upward ectopia lentis is seen in Marfan syndrome

Axial myopia due to tall stature (Option D): Tall stature with axial myopia is typical of Marfan syndrome.
